pull.title: bugfix: don't blow up on "ARG_CHECK(ctx != NULL)"
pull.body: The obvious fix for #300. I'm not sure if this should be handled in the same macro though.

events.body:
I think a better fix is to replace the affected `ARG_CHECK`s with `VERIFY_CHECK`. Or even to put a `VERIFY_CHECK` for `ctx != NULL` in the `ARG_CHECK` macro itself.

I think we'll get burned if we don't terminate the program on null context, since it's used inside of so many macros.

Agree with @apoelstra. This will just make the accidental passing of
ctx==NULL harder to discover.
On Sep 1, 2015 20:36, "Andrew Poelstra" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I think a better fix is to replace the affected ARG_CHECKs with
> VERIFY_CHECK. Or even to put a VERIFY_CHECK for ctx != NULL in the
> ARG_CHECK macro itself.
> 
> I think we'll get burned if we don't terminate the program on null
> context, since it's used inside of so many macros.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/bitcoin/secp256k1/pull/301#issuecomment-136822520.
Ok, fine by me. This was just the "fix it as it lies" change. I'd much prefer to handle the ctx logic separately from the other args.
Can you replace this with a patch that replaces any `ARG_CHECK`s on `ctx` with `VERIFY_CHECK`? (If not I can do it.)
Updated as suggested. Also moved one case where the context was checked after other arguments.
Updated again. I accidentally left the original change to the ARG_CHECK macro in, gone now.

events.message:
bugfix: "ARG_CHECK(ctx != NULL)" makes no sense

Move all context checks to VERIFY_CHECK and be sure they come before all
ARG_CHECKs.

issue.title: Bad callback logic
issue.body:
Given that ARG_CHECK is defined as:

``` c
#define ARG_CHECK(cond) do { \
    if (EXPECT(!(cond), 0)) { \
        ctx->illegal_callback.fn(#cond, ctx->illegal_callback.data); \
        return 0; \
    } \
} while(0)
```

These checks (17 of 'em from a quick grep) make no sense and are doomed to explode:

``` c
ARG_CHECK(ctx != NULL);
```

milestone.title: stable release (1.0.0-rc.1)
milestone.description:
Motivation: libsecp is already widely used today, but often in a terribly outdated version. It's likely that a release process would help with that. Moreover, it simplifies using libsecp which may prevent developers from using less well tested alternatives. Lastly, without releases it's difficult to update the library in an organized fashion and communicate these updates.

Release Goals:

- Stabilize API and documentation for functionality that exist today.
- Fix a few known bugs.
- Make ECDH non-experimental.

This milestone can be discussed in issue https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/286.
